ai-mn54:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
ai-mn54:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
ai-mn54:2.2_0: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn54:2.3_0: plunged deep into that forest grove and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn54:3.1_0: Potaliya the householder also approached that forest grove while going for a walk.
ai-mn54:3.1_1: and after approaching he plunged deep into it, and approached the Fortunate One,
ai-mn54:3.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side.
ai-mn54:3.3_0: “There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”
ai-mn54:3.4_0: When he said this, Potaliya was angry and upset. Thinking, “The ascetic Gotama addresses me as ‘householder’!” he stayed silent.
ai-mn54:3.6_0: For a third time, the Buddha said to him,
ai-mn54:3.7_0: “There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”
ai-mn54:3.8_0: When he said this, Potaliya was angry and upset. Thinking, “The ascetic Gotama addresses me as ‘householder’!” he said to the Buddha,
ai-mn54:3.9_0: “Master Gotama, it is neither proper nor appropriate for you to address me as ‘householder’.”
ai-mn54:3.10_0: “Well, householder, you have the features, attributes, and signs of a householder.”
ai-mn54:3.11_0: “Master Gotama, it’s because I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”
ai-mn54:3.12_0: “Householder, in what way have you refused all work and cut off all judgments?”
ai-mn54:3.13_0: “Master Gotama, all the money, grain, gold, and silver I used to have has been handed over to my children as their inheritance. And in this matter I do not advise or reprimand them, but live with nothing more than food and clothes.
ai-mn54:3.14_0: That’s how I have refused all work and cut off all judgments.”
ai-mn54:3.15_0: “The cutting off of judgments as you describe it is one thing, householder, but the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training is quite different.”
ai-mn54:3.16_0: “But what, sir, is cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training?
ai-mn54:3.18_0: “Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn54:4.2_0: “Householder, these eight things lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.
ai-mn54:4.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-mn54:4.4_0: Relying on not killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.
ai-mn54:4.5_0: Stealing should be given up, relying on not stealing.
ai-mn54:4.6_0: Lying should be given up, relying on speaking the truth.
ai-mn54:4.7_0: Divisive speech should be given up, relying on speech that isn’t divisive.
ai-mn54:4.8_0: greed and hate is given up, relying on discontent.
ai-mn54:4.9_0: Blaming and insulting should be given up, relying on not blaming and not insulting.
ai-mn54:4.10_0: Anger and distress should be given up, relying on not being angry and distressed.
ai-mn54:4.11_0: Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant.
ai-mn54:4.12_0: These are the eight things—stated in brief without being analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.”
ai-mn54:5.1_0: “Sir, please teach me these eight things in detail out of compassion.”
ai-mn54:5.2_0: “Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn54:6.1_0: “‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-mn54:6.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:6.3_0: ‘I am practicing for the sake of killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct.
ai-mn54:6.4_0: But if I were to kill living creatures, because of that I would reprimand myself; sensible people, after examination, would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-mn54:6.5_0: And killing living creatures is itself a fetter and a hindrance.
ai-mn54:6.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of killing living creatures do not occur in someone who does not kill living creatures.’
ai-mn54:6.7_0: ‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’
ai-mn54:6.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:7.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:7.3_0: ‘I am practicing that’s the cause, with the giving up of fetters, and the fetters are practicing to give up and cut off.
ai-mn54:7.4_0: But if I were to steal, I would criticize me by stealing ...
ai-mn54:7.5_0: And regarding this is the fetter of stealing is the hindrances.
ai-mn54:7.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of stealing do not occur in someone who refrains from stealing.’
ai-mn54:7.7_0: ‘Stealing should be given up, relying on not stealing.’
ai-mn54:7.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:8.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:8.3_0: ‘I am practicing for the sake of lying, but because of which I am practicing for the sake of unrestrained.
ai-mn54:8.4_0: But if I were to lying, others would criticize me.
ai-mn54:8.5_0: And this is how the hindrances are lying.
ai-mn54:8.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of lying do not occur in someone who is lying.’
ai-mn54:8.7_0: ‘Though words should be given up, relying on speech.’
ai-mn54:8.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:9.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:9.4_0: But if I were to expel divisive speech, harsh speech, and coarse speech, I would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-mn54:9.5_0: And killing living creatures is itself a fetter and a hindrance.
ai-mn54:9.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of divisive speech do not occur in someone who is divisive speech.’
ai-mn54:9.7_0: Divisive speech should be given up, relying on speech that isn’t divisive.
ai-mn54:9.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:10.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:10.3_0: ‘I’m practicing for the sake of greed, hate, and delusion, and practicing well.
ai-mn54:10.4_0: But if I were to swallow me by lust, sensible people would get sensible and neglected. And when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-mn54:10.5_0: And this is the fetter of the fetters that is hindrance.
ai-mn54:10.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of greed, hate, and delusion that might arise because of undertaking these things.’
ai-mn54:10.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:11.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:11.3_0: ‘I am practicing for the sake of blamelessness, but practicing to give up and cut off.
ai-mn54:11.4_0: But if I were to sit on blameless, sensible people would criticize me.
ai-mn54:11.5_0: And this is the hindrance of relishing.
ai-mn54:11.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of resentment.’
ai-mn54:11.7_0: ‘Arrogance should be given up, relying on not blaming and not insulting.’
ai-mn54:11.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:12.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:12.3_0: ‘I’m irritable, distress, and fickle are practicing for giving up and fetters.
ai-mn54:12.4_0: But if I were to extinguish anger, distress, and fever; giving up anger and distress, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
ai-mn54:12.5_0: And this is the hindrance of anger and distress are irritable.
ai-mn54:12.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of anger, distress, and feverish defilements that might arise because of anger and distress do not arise when they are avoided.’
ai-mn54:12.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:13.1_0: Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
ai-mn54:13.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:13.3_0: ‘I am practicing for the sake of unbroken, improvement, and they are practicing to give up and cut off.
ai-mn54:13.4_0: But if I were to expel me, they would criticize me.
ai-mn54:13.5_0: And this is the fetter of the fetters that is hindrance.
ai-mn54:13.6_0: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of arrogance do not occur in someone who is not arrogant.’
ai-mn54:13.7_0: ‘Arrogance should be given up by not being arrogant.’
ai-mn54:13.8_0: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
ai-mn54:14.1_0: These are the eight things—stated in brief without being analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of judgments in the noble one’s training.
ai-mn54:14.2_0: But just this much does not constitute the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.”
ai-mn54:14.3_0: “But, sir, how is there the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?
ai-mn54:14.5_0: “Well then, householder, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn54:15.1_0: “Householder, suppose a dog weak with hunger was hanging around a butcher’s shop.
ai-mn54:15.2_0: Then a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
ai-mn54:15.4_0: Gnawing on such a fleshless skeleton, would that dog still get rid of its hunger?”
ai-mn54:15.7_0: Because that skeleton is scraped clean of flesh and smeared in blood.
ai-mn54:15.8_0: That dog observance will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
ai-mn54:15.9_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:15.10_0: ‘With the simile of a skeleton the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
ai-mn54:15.11_0: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they develop the equanimity that is diversified, having made equanimity based on diversity in materiality.
ai-mn54:16.1_0: Suppose a vulture or a crow or a hawk was to grab a lump of meat and fly away.
ai-mn54:16.2_0: Other vultures, crows, and hawks would keep chasing it, pecking and clawing.
ai-mn54:16.4_0: If that vulture, crow, or hawk doesn’t quickly let go of that lump of meat, wouldn’t that result in death or deadly suffering for them?”
ai-mn54:16.6_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:16.7_0: ‘With the simile of a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
ai-mn54:16.8_0: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they develop the equanimity that is diversified, having made equanimity based on diversity in materiality.
ai-mn54:17.1_0: “Suppose a person carrying a blazing grass torch was to walk against the wind.
ai-mn54:17.3_0: If that person were to burn that blazing grass, or burn them, it would result in death or deadly pain.”
ai-mn54:17.5_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:17.6_0: ‘With the Fortunate One said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
ai-mn54:17.7_0: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they develop it and cultivate it.
ai-mn54:18.1_0: “Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
ai-mn54:18.2_0: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
ai-mn54:18.3_0: Then two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.
ai-mn54:18.5_0: Wouldn’t that person writhe and struggle to and fro?”
ai-mn54:18.8_0: For that person knows: ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that’d result in my death or deadly pain.’” ...
ai-mn54:18.9_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:18.11_0: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they develop it and cultivate it.
ai-mn54:19.1_0: Suppose a person was to see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.
ai-mn54:19.2_0: But when they woke they couldn’t see them at all. ...
ai-mn54:19.3_0: In the same way, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:19.4_0: ‘The Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ ...
ai-mn54:19.5_0: they develop it in a bundle of rebirth,
ai-mn54:20.1_0: Suppose a man had borrowed some goods—a gentleman’s carriage and fine jewelled earrings—
ai-mn54:20.2_0: and preceded and surrounded by these he proceeded through the middle of Āpaṇa.
ai-mn54:20.3_0: When people saw him they’d say:
ai-mn54:20.4_0: ‘So it seems that a man enjoys wealth!’
ai-mn54:20.5_0: But when the owners saw him, they’d take back what was theirs.
ai-mn54:20.6_0: What do you think of this person’s quite different from that person’s view?”
ai-mn54:20.9_0: Because the owners took back what was theirs.” ...
ai-mn54:20.10_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:20.11_0: ‘With the Fortunate One said this to the world ...’
ai-mn54:20.12_0: they develop it in a bundle of rebirth,
ai-mn54:21.1_0: Suppose there was a village or town not far from a town or village.
ai-mn54:21.2_0: And there was a tree laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit had fallen to the ground.
ai-mn54:21.3_0: And along came a person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit.
ai-mn54:21.4_0: Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit.
ai-mn54:21.6_0: ‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground.
ai-mn54:21.7_0: But I know how to climb a tree.
ai-mn54:21.8_0: Why don’t I climb the tree, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’
ai-mn54:21.9_0: So they’d climb the tree, eat as much as they like, then fill the pouch.
ai-mn54:21.10_0: And along would come a second person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit, carrying a sharp axe.
ai-mn54:21.11_0: Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit.
ai-mn54:21.13_0: ‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground.
ai-mn54:21.14_0: But I don’t know how to climb a tree.
ai-mn54:21.15_0: Why don’t I chop this tree down at the root, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’
ai-mn54:21.16_0: And so they’d chop the tree down at the root.
ai-mn54:21.18_0: Suppose that person was to trunk, so that person wouldn’t have come down some tree trunk, fear, and terrified, would result in death or deadly pain.”
ai-mn54:21.20_0: “In the same way, householder, a noble disciple reflects:
ai-mn54:21.21_0: ‘With the simile of the fruit tree the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
ai-mn54:21.22_0: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they develop the equanimity that is diversified, having made equanimity based on diversity in materiality.
ai-mn54:22.1_0: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple recollects their many kinds of past lives.
ai-mn54:22.2_1: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-mn54:23.1_0: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. ...
ai-mn54:23.1_1: and he knows beings arise according to their (good and bad) actions...
ai-mn54:24.1_0: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn54:25.1_0: That’s how there is the cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.
ai-mn54:25.3_0: astute, would you see any cutting off of judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?”
ai-mn54:25.4_0: “Who am I compared to one who has cut off judgments in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?
ai-mn54:25.6_0: Sir, I used to think that the wanderers following other paths were thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they were not actually thoroughbreds.
ai-mn54:25.7_0: I thought that the mendicants were not thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they actually were thoroughbreds.
ai-mn54:25.8_0: But now I shall understand that the wanderers following other paths are not actually thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly.
ai-mn54:25.9_0: I shall know that the mendicants were thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly, but they actually were thoroughbreds.
ai-mn54:25.10_0: The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!
ai-mn54:26.1_0: Excellent, reverend Sir! Excellent, reverend Sir!
ai-mn54:26.2_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-mn54:26.2_1: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-mn54:26.3_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the Teaching, and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-mn54:26.4_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-mn54:26.5_0: The fourth section on the legal procedure, is finished.
